i always thought it was pretty obvious.

is there really another way to explain it?
comment_1:
i found this on faqs.org/lyrics/…


Another One Bites The Dust by Queen was released in 1980 and reached number 1 in the US charts and number 7 in the UK charts.

The lyrics to this song were inspired after the writer saw a documentary on the St. Valentines day Massacre.

If you don't know that it is quite hard to understand what the lyrics are about.

They describe a man walking silently down a street with his hat covering his face carrying a machine gun.

The words of the song are building up an atmosphere describing what is about to happen, is there going to be some kind if fight and if so who with, who will he start shooting?

The song then takes a twist when he starts singing about someone who has wronged him, a lover perhaps, who left him with nothing and with nowhere to live.

The song ends with bullets being fired and another one biting the dust so you can only imagine that he has gone looking for an ex lover and he has killed them for the way they treated him.

There is some controversy over this song because it is claimed that if it is played backwards you can hear the words 'Decide to smoke marijuana' several times quite clearly.

comment_6:
You're all wrong I'm afraid; the lyrics are inspired by the original Space Invaders arcade game - simple as that.

"Out of the doorway the bullets rip..." - moving out from behind the shield

"... to the sound of the beat" - remember how the game had that beat that got faster and faster in time with the missiles

"How do you think I'm going to get along
Without you when you're gone" - what will you do when you've finished the game ? 

"You took me for everything that I had
And kicked me out on my own" - You've spent all your money on it & had to leave the arcade

"Another one bites the dust, and another one gone and another one gone etc ..." - well there were an awful lot of invaders on the screen

comment_8:
All of the ideas that it's about marijuana are ridiculous...even if it does sound like that when played backwards, it was probably coincidential. Plus the power of suggestion may have something to do with it. People say, "It sounds like, 'It's fun to smoke marijuana' when played backwards" so when you play it backwards, you're looking for that phrase...if you hadn't been told otherwise, it might not sound so much like it. I dunno, I haven't actually heard it played backwards, I might be wrong, but I don't think it's about marijuana. And besides, I've heard that song lots of times, and I don't think any more of marijuana than I did before!

Sorry, I like to rant...so anyway, the meaning...not too deep, it just sounds like it's about violence on the streets is some places and how so many people are dying and how awful it is. Since John Deacon doesn't write terrible complex songs, I don't think it's about marriage, but I wouldn't be surprised if it was: "There are plenty of ways that you can hurt a man 
And bring him to the ground 
You can beat him 
You can cheat him 
You can treat him bad and leave him 
When he's down"

Just one question though...why do people think that so many Queen songs are a reference to Freddie's AIDS? A lot of these songs they think have to do with AIDS were a) written before Freddie new he had AIDS, b) written by another band member, or c) all of the above.

Ok, I'm done! :D
comment_9: In the Eighth grade my music teacher told us that there was a subliminal message in the song the said "you should smoke marijauna." None of use believed it to be possible but the next day my teacher brought an original copy of this song put the needle of the record player on the record and spun it backwards and when turned at the correct speed the whole class clearly heard "you should smoke marijauna". I am not lying and I am not saying tha Queen was trying to start some drug revolution. They could simply have done it as a joke but the fact is that the encoded message myth is true.

comment_17: Ok. I'd like to share some sort of physicians point of view. Spech in general is a wave of a specific amplitude and frequency, moving air and thus creating a, for human standards, sound. Vowels generally spoken are a constant wave of a specific frequency, amplitude and phase, while consonants are waves of different type woven together. No a vowel will sound the same backward masked, but in combination with consonants it may sound somehow like a different word spoken. So, except for some sarcastic comments about backward masking by iron maiden and such, most songs, reversed, will sound like _some_ strangely pronouncated words, not necessarly making any sense. Now give us a break.

But I have no real basis for that, just the feeling Iget from the song, so you can think whatever you want.
comment_19: Do you know the chances of a clear sentence played backwards coming out as another clear sentence? Unless the sentence is a string of random vowels, I'd say about 1,000,000 to 1. Backwards speech sounds like Satanic messages because backwards speech is mostly gibberish, so it sounds like "speaking in tongues". For it to be that clear, it would need to be double-tracked somehow, and the nature of sounds tells us that then we would hear in the backround a weird phrase backwards, and when played backwards we would hear a clear sentence and ANOTHER weird phrase backwards. The power of suggestion is strong. Placebos, anyone?

comment_22:
I did an interesting experiment involving this song the other day.  I played the chorus backwards for people, and asked them to identify anything they understood.  NO ONE out of forty people heard anything understandable, only a few people recognized it as singing without being told it was a song played backwards.  After this, I played it again tell them it was a rock and roll song, and there is a hidden message in the backwards play.  Four people heard "marijuana," though a greater number (ten) heard "carolina."  After I told them "It says 'it's fun to smoke marijuana'," nearly everyone heard it.

Interesting, right?

comment_25:
In the early 1990's I watched a televangelist on TV do a program on backmasking.  I was hoping to find out what the Beatles were really saying in Strawberry Fields Forever.  The show was disappointing on that issue, but the host ranted on and on about satanic messages decoded by playing pop music backwards.  To buy into his argument, you needed to accept the theory that the human mind can, on a sub-conscious level, process words played backwards  (my opinion on the subject is pretty firm, but beyond the scope of this forum).   To support his position he played segments of a few tunes--The Beatles, The Stones, and quite a bit of Led Zeppelin--most of which left me saying to myself, "well, yeah, if you really use your imagination you could say it sounds like that."  His last example was Another One Bites the Dust which to me sounded unmistakeably like "start to smoke marijuana."  I feel that the recording wasn't altered.  The show's producers could have remixed some of the other music to make a better case for satanic messages, and clearly they didn't.  I can't at this time put much stock in the theory that Another One Bites the Dust contains a message from satan.  My theory is as follows:
    A writer in the recording industry wants to get the religous right upset about something.  He spends a night, maybe several, speaking various short messages into a recorder and playing them backwards.  I can just see him saying "Impeach Reagan...that sounds awful...Buy Pornography...that doesn't sound like anything...Kill the Pope...nothing!"  then finally "Start to smoke marijuana...another one..bites...the dust...HEY!  If we say another one bites the dust at the right tempo, it'll sound just like start to smoke marijuana!  The Moral Majority will wet itself!  So the guy wrote a song around the phrase "another one bites the dust."
    Just my theory.

comment_28:
i think it's a good song... not my most favorite Queen song but definitely one of their best... 
and i love it. :D

although when anybody mentions Queen, the first song that comes to mind is Bohemian Rapsody, but another one bites the dust is "queen's best selling and biggest hit to date..." at least according to several articles that i've read.
also initially roger and brian weren't too keen on this song but freddie believed in it. john got freddie's support so it happened.
i also read in an interview of john that he said michael jackson was their fan.. michael voted for this song so they released it as a single...
queen's amazing.. it's rare to find a song that has beat so recognizeable, that anybody can guess the title. we will rock u, under pressure, another one bites the dust... these songs rock!!

i guess the phenomenal success of this single prompted others to search for hidden meaning... if it's not this popular, i don't think anybody will bother playing it backwards or if they did, i don't think anybody will pay attention to it enough to find a message when it's played reversely.
i also think the video enhanced everyone's imagination and convinced more people that it has hidden meaning... freddie looks possitivelly menacing with his cap w/ horns...

i'm a God-fearing person and i love queen.. i certainly hope that whatever backward message it has was not placed deliberately and won't do any lasting damage to anybody who listened.

QUEEN rules!! GOD SAVE THE QUEEN!!

comment_42:
Let's be sensible about this. Here's a little experiment. Plug a mic into your PC. Record yourself saying, at normal speed, in your normal speaking voice, the phrase "Another one bites the dust".

Now take your recording and play it backwards. You will hear yourself, (with something resembling a Russian accent) saying something which SOUNDS a bit like "Start to smoke marijuana". No tricks, no extra overdubs, no studio wizardry, just YOUR voice. YOU said it!

So, either it's a coincidence, or they found out that it worked and wrote the song around that phrase.

comment_65: I'll chime in with another comment on this page.  I was talking about this with my teenaged daughter, and she mentioned the alleged backmasking.  I was incredulous, but remembered that it'd be easy as pie to check with a 4-track recorder (which I had).  We tried the experiment.  Damned if I didn't come out a believer!  The message *is* as clear as a bell!  Plus, I believe they did it on purpose:  I mean, why the heck not?  It's not some kind of big conspiracy theory to suggest that people would think this was a fun thing to do, and it wouldn't be all that hard.  Just play the target message backwards, see if it sounds like something grammatical, and if it does, bingo!  Just incorporate that grammatical message as a bullet in your hit song and you're ready to bear Satan's love child!  Ha!

comment_95: I always loved Queen and every element of this song is perfect.  I have an old audio tape by Pastor Gary Greenwald called Rock-A-Bye Baby.  It came out around the time of the PMRC attempted to censor and put the warning labels on albums.  He is formerly from the rock music industry turned evangelist.  Another One Bites the Dust and several other rock songs are played backwards.  There are some possible messages (subject to interpretation) on the tape but the Pastor always tells the listeners what they'll hear beforehand.  I think rock lyrics played forward are controverseal enough.  There would not be any need to ever put backwards masking on recordings other than to spite holy rollers.  I love the music so much Iâd hate to see evangelists get there way.  Long but informative site:  religioustolerance.org/…

comment_157:
Backmasked messages arent supposed to be 100 percent clear and would be mere impossible to do.

To mackmask, first you'd have to record yourself saying "Its fun to smoke marijuana", then play it backwards, slow it down alot ot hear its correctly, then say words that sounds like the message in backwards, so when played forwards and reversed you get the message. And you cant really just record it, reverse and get the message, because everyones voice and pronounciation is different.

Either way, this doesnt mean it was put in the song purposly, and has just as much chance as being a coincidence then not being one

You people are stupid and just think every song is about drugs. How about listening to the song (sober) for once and maybe you will understand the lyrics.

"Stupidity is learned not taught" - someone smarter than you
comment_177: Since everyone is speculating on the meaning of this song, I, too will jump on the "band wagon", no pun intended. First I have too say that this song is clearly one of the "grooviest" songs of all time. It has a "way groovy" 70's sound to it, and from my research this was no accident. As with a lot of songs (poetry + music= song), there is not simply one meaning, and it is for each to interpret. Based on the lyrics themselves and the man who wrote them, knowing his sexual preference as heterosexual even though the man who actually sings the song is homosexual (look these facts up for yourself-you have to do your own homework) I believe this has a partially, as with a lot of songs, a "love/heart broken/bitterness" underlying theme in this song, but that is not all that is there. I believe that the writer has successfully drawn exquisite analogies and painted such a vivid picture with these lyrics, he has to have witnessed firsthand some sort of dangerous situation involving perhaps the death of someone, whether it was by drug use, or perhaps even literally by a gun. He's (Steve) is walking "warily down the street" with his hat "brim pulled way down low" (clearly he is in a bad part of town somewhere), again either literally, or figuratively. The only sound anyone can hear is "the sound of his own feet" and be prepared with "machine guns ready to go". "Are you ready, are you ready for this. Are you hanging on the edge of your seat. Out of the doorway the bullets rip to the sound of the beat. Another one bites the dust (did he just see someone get shot?) And another one gone (he's seen this before)...Hey, I'm gonna get you, too (Who are you? Drug abuse?) Another one bites the dust." That's how you break down a poem. Great poem, set to great music= FABULOUS SONG. No wonder this one did so well for QUEEN. It's been fun.
